metadata.title: ICU Delirium
synonyms: ” or “induced” may be used with the word delirium
anatomical location body part affected: Brain, central nervous system (CNS)/cognitive function; motor and sensory function
description: Delirium is classified in DSM-5  as a neurocognitive disorder of global brain failure characterized by acute disturbances in attention, awareness, and cognition that vary in severity over time.(1) Deficits can occur in memory, visual-spatialorientation, language, and perception. Additional psychomotor disturbances occur in three subtypes: hyperactive, hypoactive, or mixed state

Patients with delirium may fluctuate between states of hyperactivity and hypoactivity(1,2,27) –Hyperactive state is more common and often is associated with medication side effects and drug withdrawal -Sometimes called “ICU psychosis”(2) –Hypoactive state is more frequent in older adults -Sometimes called “quiet delirium”(2) –Mixed states: hyper-  and hypoactive states fluctuate
ICU delirium is associated with disturbances in the sleep-wake  cycle (e.g., daytime sleepiness, nighttime agitation, reversal of night-day  sleep cycle)(1,27)

Patients with delirium may also exhibit emotional disturbances (e.g., anxiety, fear, depression, irritability, anger, euphoria, apathy)(1,27) –Emotional statesmay shift rapidly –Emotional states are characterized by calling out, screaming, cursing, muttering, moaning, or other sounds –Emotional disturbances occurmore commonly at night and under conditions when stimulation and environmental cues are lacking
ICU delirium is an independent predictor of mortality and morbidity and is associated with prolonged hospital and ICU stays(3)
In acute care centers, the incidence of delirium can be as high as 87% among patients with psychiatric syndromes(27)

Critically ill patients in the ICU are routinely monitored for delirium using the American College of Critical Care Medicine (ACCCM)/Society of Critical Care Medicine (SCCM) clinical practice guidelines for pain, agitation, and delirium (PAD)(4)

Patient management of delirium in the ICU often follows the ABCDEF bundle developed by SCCM. It consists of the following:(5) –A – Assess,prevent, manage pain  –B – Both spontaneous awakening trials and spontaneous breathing trials –C – Choice of analgesia and sedation –D – Delirium: Assess, prevent, manage –E – Early mobility and exercise –F – Family engagement and empowerment -Authors of a cohort study found that use of the ABCDE (F was added to the bundle after the study started) for patient management over 18 months increased the number of days of breathing without assistance, reduced delirium onset by about 50%, and permitted greatermobilization than in patients treated with usual care(6)
About 2 of 3 patients in the ICU develop delirium and 7 of 10 patients on ventilators in the ICU develop delirium(7)

The prevalence of delirium diagnosed in patients admitted to hospital ranges from 14% to 24%, while the incidence of delirium arising during hospitalization ranges from 6% to 56%(1) –Delirium occurs in 15% to 53% of older adults postoperatively and in 70% to 87% of older adults in the ICU –Authors of a 2018 systematic review conducted in the Netherlands found an incidence rate of delirium in older ICU patients of 29%(33)
Twenty-five  percent of children in the cardiac ICU develop delirium(35)
The nonpharmacological approach to management of ICU delirium involves restoration of senses, early mobilization, physiotherapy, improvement in sleep hygiene and family involvement(8)
Prevention of ICU delirium is considered of great importance and is covered in the Maintenance and Prevention  section towards the end of this Clinical Review

ICD-10 codes.The: number of the disorder is followed by the course (i.e., acute, persistent), followed by the level of psychomotor activity (i.e., hyperactive, hypoactive, mixed level of activity) (ICD codes are provided for reference only and not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients with ICU delirium may present with(7) –Hypoactivity,hyperactivity, or a combination of each –Confusion  –Aggressive behavior –Inappropriate language –Inattentiveness, distraction, inability to follow directions –Not oriented to time or place –Hallucinations –Behavioral or emotional changes from baseline –Changes in sleeping habits –Abnormal movements (tremors) –Memory problems Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Make note of all monitors, devices, electrodes, lines, and tubes
Presence of certain devices may prevent complete assessment (e.g., traction, hemodialysis, chest tubes, Swan-Ganz catheter, arterial lines)

If client is on ventilator, note settings and familiarize self with alarms that may be triggered during assessment –Check airway stability –Avoid excessive movement of artificial airway to avoid possible tracheal irritation, accidental extubation, or movement of airway into single mainstem bronchus
Document BP, HR, oxygen saturation (O2 sat), and respiratory rate prior to initiating exam –Avoid excessive cuff inflation pressure when measuring BP
Be sure to maintain slack in tubing and lines when changing positions to avoid dislodgement

Signs that indicate interrupting testing or treatment include intense sensation of dyspnea, arrhythmia, abnormal increase in HR, drop in O2 sat below 80% (desaturation [desat]), abnormal increase or decrease in BP (e.g., mobility-related hypotension)
Patient’s pain should be respected. Pain can be a major cause of agitation and delirium in the ICU

Patient’s attentiveness, awareness, and orientation should be constantly evaluated during examination. If patient shows increased combativeness/aggression, lethargy, or disorientation, the physical examination should be discontinued

Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Signs that indicate a patient on mechanical ventilation may be unstable include:(#) –Mean arterial BP < 65 mmHg or more than 110 mmHg, or systolic BP > 200 mmHg –HR < 40 beats per minute (bpm) or > 130 bpm –Respiratory rate < 5 breaths per minute or more than 40 breaths per minute or pulse oximetry < 88% –Additional contraindications to the initiation  of therapeutic exercise -Raised intracranial pressure, active gastrointestinal blood loss; active myocardial ischemia, continuing procedures including intermittent hemodialysis (but not including continuous ultrafiltration or hemodialysis); patient agitation that needed increase sedative administration in the past 30 minutes; and unsecure airway –Additional contraindications to continuing  therapeutic exercise -Marked ventilator asynchrony, patient distress (evidenced by non-verbal  cues and gestures); patient becoming physically combative; new arrhythmia, concern for myocardial ischemia; and concern for airway device integrity

A screening algorithm for patient mobilization in the ICU developed at Johns Hopkins has the following requirements:(#) –Prior to consulting therapist for rehabilitation: -Eyes open to verbal stimulation -Respiratory criteria -Fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) < 0.6 (normal air in well-ventilated  room is 0.79) -Positive and expiratory pressure (PEEP) < 10 cm H 2O -Circulatory criteria -No new or increased vasopressor dose within last 2 hours -No continuous infusion of vasodilator medication -No addition of new antiarrhythmic agent -No new cardiac ischemia –Once consulted for therapy -Pulse oximetry ≥ 88% -Respiratory rate ≤ 45 breaths per minute  -Arterial pH ≥ 7.25 -Mean arterial pressure between 55 and 140 mmHg -No new deep venous thrombosis (DVT)

causes:: Anoxia or chemical changes in brain(7)
Use of alcohol, sedatives, or opioids/opiates/narcotics(7)
Intensive post-op  care following cardiac surgery(32)

Multi-bed  ICU rooms may increase the risk of delirium because of more noise, sleep disruption, activity, and patient carecompared to single-bed  ICU rooms) (9)–Authors of a retrospective study of 1,253 patients admitted to the ICU identified these factors as associated with thedevelopment of delirium: multi-bed  rooms, older age, ICU-acquired  infection, and higher Simplified Acute PhysiologyScore 3 and Sequential Organ Failure Assessment score(9)

Mechanical ventilation–Delirium is 1.5 to 4.1 times more likely to develop in ICU patients receiving mechanical ventilation(10)-Based on a murine model, aberrant vagal sensory input that drives sustained dopamine D2 receptor signaling in thehippocampal formation can induce neural apoptosis–For additional information on mechanical ventilation, see the Clinical Review…Mechanical Ventilation and PhysicalTherapy, CINAHL Topic ID number T708957
pathogenesis:: The pathophysiology of delirium remains poorly understood(11,27)–Leading hypotheses focus on-Neurotransmission imbalance: e.g.,decreased cholinergic activity and increased dopaminergic activity in the CNScaused by multiple precipitants(27)-Inflammation:e.g., increased levels of pro-inflammatory  cytokines-Authors of a cross-sectional  study (n = 31 patients with delirium and 47 non-delirium patients admitted to ICU)in Brazil found higher levels of the inflammation biomarkers soluble TNF receptor-1  and -2, adiponectin, andinterleukin-1β in the patients with delirium(12)-Acute stress: aberrant stress responses in patients with delirium often follow physical or psychological stress-The greater incidence of ICU delirium in older adults may be due to their more prolonged stress responsesas comparedto younger persons(11)
Anatomic deficits associated with cognitive impairment in higher cortical areas of the brain were found in studies thatanalyzed CT and MRI scans of persons with delirium(23)
In acute stroke, the etiology of delirium has been associated with hypoxia, inflammatory processes, disruption ofneurotransmitter signals, and presence of other internal or external risk factors(36)

Antipsychotics may be indicated for behaviors in the ICU associated with psychosis. However,authors of a systematicreview with meta-analysis  of RCTs found that the use of antipsychoticsdid not change delirium duration, severity, or lengthof stayin hospital or ICU(24)
risk factors:: The risk factors for delirium are related to the patient’s acute and chronic clinical condition, treatment, and environment(9)
Independent risk factors associated with delirium:(30)–Older age–Hypertension–COPD–Corticosteroid use–Sedation
Delirium while in the ICU is related to previous comorbidities, severity of current illness, and withdrawal of drugs andtobacco(30)

Previous comorbiditiesAcute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is associated with a greater risk for ICU delirium thanmechanical ventilation alone(13)–In-hospital  mortality due to ARDS is associated with delirium and coma

The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Edition (DSM-5), identifies the following risk factors fordelirium:(1)–Age-Older adults are more susceptible-Susceptibility to delirium in infancy through childhood may be greater than in early and middle adulthood-Usually related to febrile illness or medications–Functional impairment–Immobility–History of falls–Low levels of activity–Use of drugs and medications with psychoactive properties (particularly alcohol and anticholinergics)–Major and mild neurocognitive disorders
Other identified risk factors–After hip or heart surgery(7)–Poor eyesight or poor hearing(7)–Mechanical ventilation(10)

overall contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician

As ICU delirium is the result of underlying condition(s), consult the Clinical Review  associated with the specific patient conditionfor additional contraindications/precautions for treatment and examination

Contraindications to exercise/training(14) High respiratory support requirements Medical instability Cardiovascular instability, including blood pressure (BP) and heart rate (HR) fluctuations with position changes Unstable neurological status (e.g., labile or elevated intracranial pressure) Unstable fractures, unstable spinal cord Thrombophlebitis, embolism Ventricular tachycardia and other dangerous arrhythmias, new arrhythmias Recent myocardial infarction (MI) Unstable angina Acute congestive heart failure (CHF) Myocarditis  Acute infection Sedation, neuromuscular blocking agents
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: What is the reason for the current referral? What is felt to be the underlying condition for the ICU delirium present? Is it caused by a medical condition, substance intoxication or withdrawal? Is it medication-induced  or from multiple etiologies? Or, is the cause of the delirium unknown?

course of treatment.medical management: Admission history, surgical history if applicable, ICU history, pulmonary ventilation history if applicable. Any complications? Has the ICU staff been doing routine screenings for delirium? When was delirium noticed? Is it consistent? How is the delirium being managed in the ICU?
course of treatment.medications: Medications may be numerous in ICU setting and depend on underlying condition(s). Make note of sedation, use of neuromuscular blocking agents, cardiac medications, bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and analgesics Evidence-based  pharmacological treatments for delirium are minimal and most have limited applications(11)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests will depend on underlying condition. Typical examples in the acute care setting include:
Laboratory tests to determine medical conditions (or intoxication/withdrawal states)(1)
There is often a generalized slowing on EEG or there can be fast activity in some cases of alcohol withdrawal delirium. EEG is not sensitive and specific enough for diagnostic use(1)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Note all factors that have been associated with delirium. Delirium is described as hypoactive, hyperactive, or mixed depending on activity and tends to fluctuate in severity throughout the day symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: In addition to pain, document other symptomssuch as agitation, lack of attention/awareness, disturbances in cognition (e.g., memory deficit, impaired language, visual-spatial  ability, or perception),aggressive behavior, inappropriate language, disorientation, hallucinations, behavioral and emotional changes, abnormal movements. Document nature of symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night(a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to external variables including medication, noting duration and frequency of
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. It is typical in the ICU for the sleep cycle to be disturbed; sleep disturbances are both a risk for and a symptom of ICU delirium
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note use of supplemental oxygen and mechanical ventilator. Does respiratory status change when patient is experiencing delirium?mode, FiO2, respiratory rate, tidal volume, etc. -PEEP in cm H 2O -Oxygen saturation levels -Peak airway pressure -Synchrony with ventilator (vs. fighting the ventilator) -Arterial blood gases (ABGs) -Attempts at weaning, duration of periods of spontaneous breathing and respiration rate  -Results from pulmonary function tests -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -Learning will likely be impaired by ICU delirium symptoms and treatment -If Yes, describe

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has patient experienced ICU delirium in past?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders (fractures), dementia, neuromuscular disorders, infections COPD,hypertension, tobacco and alcohol abuse, steroid use, and sedation are all considered risk factors for ICU delirium(4)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken. Prior medications may be implicated in cause of admission and delirium

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Document any substance or alcohol abuse that may have contributed to current condition
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document prior functional level as reported by patient and family
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home and if any modifications are necessary. This is relevant for long-term  planning, as client may have symptoms of delirium past discharge -Delirium is associated with increased functional decline and risk of institutional placement(1)

relevant tests and measures.general: While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to ›Relevant tests and measures:  While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting. As ICU delirium can vary in severity over the course of a day, both examination and treatment should occur when sedation is interrupted for best patient response to tests
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document if patient is using and if he or she is using correctly, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.balance: Observe client in sitting and, if possible, standingfor any balance deficits. Functional Reach Test (FRT) or Timed-up  and go (TUG) can be used if patient is able and cooperates
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess vital signs and O2 sat throughout exam, especially if client is ventilator-dependent
Assess cough for effectiveness and assess sputum if productive

If possible for the patient and feasible in the clinic, the Timed 100-Meter  Walk Test (T100MW) can be used to assess walking endurance.Patient effort can be rated using the Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale. Authors of a validity study (n = 141 MS patients and 104 healthy controls) in Belgium found that theT100MW correlated more favorably with maximum walking distance than the 25-foot walk test(28)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulses in all limbs. In the ICU setting, immobility in bed is a risk factor for DVT and for skin breakdownA thorough assessment of cranial and peripheral nerve integrity may be indicated depending on the underlying conditionIn the acute setting, patients may be very dependent in functional mobility, due to the presence of apparatus and lines –Assess tolerance for upright position and transfers, as able –The FIM or the Barthel Index of Activities of Daily Living may be used for an objective measurement, if appropriate
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: If patient is ambulatory, assess for safety and preferred walking speed with 10-meter  walk test (10MWT) or 25-foot  timed walk test. Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) may be appropriateAssess for contracturesAssess tone and ability of patient to move limbs on verbal command
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Asses limb muscle strength with manual muscle testing (MMT) as indicated
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and/or passive ROM as indicatedTest as able in the acute care setting
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Test as applicable to the patient’s underlying condition
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –The CAM-ICU  is a tool used to assess delirium in critically ill patients that is both valid and reliable. This test can be performed in < 1 minute, requires minimal training, and has been translated into 26 languages(31) –The Intensive Care Delirium Screening Checklist (ICDSC) is an 8-item  checklist to assess delirium symptoms. It is considered both valid and reliable in assessing for delirium in critically ill patients(31) –pCAM-ICU  can be used in pediatric population(27)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: In the ICU, patients (especially those on mechanical ventilators) are frequently sedated to control pain, breathing, agitation, and tachycardia. Occupational therapy (OT) and physical therapy (PT) should be coordinated with daily interruption of sedative(#) –TheConfusion Assessment Method for the ICU (CAM-ICU)  is commonly used to assess delirium during ICU stay.(37)(2) -There has been an acute change from mental status baseline OR the patient’s mental status has fluctuated during past 24 hoursIf the patient has more than two errors during the following test -“Squeeze my hand when I say the letter ‘A’”S A V E A H A R TRichmond Agitation-Sedation  Scale (RASS) score is other than zero -If RASS is zero, patient can still be considered delirious if there is evidence of disorganized thinking (e.g., will a stone float on water? Does one pound weigh more than two?) –The pCAM-ICU  can be used in the pediatric population. It is recommended that pediatric patients in the ICU be screened twice daily(25) –Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status (RBANS) is a quick individualized battery assessment tool to measure cognitive decline or improvement. Considered to have great sensitivity(34) –Trail Making Test (TMT) is a neuropsychological assessment used to track visual attention and task switching. Considered to have great sensitivity(34)

contraindications precautions: Mean arterial BP < 65 mmHg or more than 110 mmHg or systolic BP > 200 mmHg
HR < 40 beats per minute (bpm) or > 130 bpm
Respiratory rate < 5 breaths per minute or more than 40 breaths per minute or O2 sat by pulse oximetry < 88%

Additional contraindications to the initiation of therapeutic exercise  -Raised intracranial pressure, active gastrointestinal blood loss; active myocardial ischemia, continuing procedures including intermittent hemodialysis (but not including continuous ultrafiltration or hemodialysis); patient agitation that needed increase sedative administration in the past 30 minutes; and unsecure airway

Additional contraindications to the continuation of therapeutic exercise -Marked ventilator asynchrony, patient distress (evidenced by non-verbal  cues and gestures); patient becoming physically combative; new arrhythmias, concern for myocardial ischemia; and concern for airway device integrity

Prior to consulting therapist for rehabilitation: -Eyes open to verbal stimulation -Respiratory criteria -FiO2 < 0.6 -PEEP < 10 cm H 2O -Circulatory criteria -No new or increased vasopressor dose within last 2 hours -No continuous infusion of vasodilator medication -No addition of new antiarrhythmic agent -No new cardiac ischemia

Once consulted for therapy, all the following are required: -Pulse oximetry ≥ 88 % -Respiratory rate ≤ 45 breaths per minute -Arterial pH ≥ 7.25 -Mean arterial pressure between 55 and 140 mmHg -No new DVT

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: ICU delirium with referral to mobilize patient/reduced strength, ROM, and functional status due to prolonged immobility; decreased cognition, awareness, attention
assessment plan of care.rule out: Psychotic disorders and bipolar and depressive disorders with psychotic features(1) Acute stress disorder (caused by severetrauma)(1) Malingering and factitious disorder(if medical condition or substance is absent)(1) Other neurocognitive disorders (NCD), especially in older adults(1) –When distinguishing between delirium and dementia, it is common to use acuteness of onset and temporal course to diagnose delirium. However, in older adults with prior unrecognized NCD or who develop persistent cognitive impairment following an episode of delirium, making this distinction may be difficult because patients who develop delirium may have dementia-like  cognitive problems that last for months(1,7)
prognosis: In hospital settings delirium usually lasts about a week, but some symptoms can persist even after patient is discharged from hospital(1)
Early recognition and treatment of underlying cause is important to prevent more serious consequences (e.g., coma, seizures, death)(1)

Mortality among hospitalized patients with delirium is high, with as many as 40% dying within a year after diagnosis. Mortality is particularly high among those who have malignanciesand other significant underlying medical illness(1)

Hospitalized patients 65 years and older with delirium have 3 times the risk of nursing home placement and 3 times the functional decline when compared to hospitalized patients without delirium at discharge and 3 months post discharge(1)

Rapidly reversible sedation-related  delirium (delirium that stops shortly after sedative interruption) does not signify the same poor prognosis as delirium that persists despite a short period of sedative interruption(15)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A multidisciplinary approach is commonly used in the care of patients in the ICU. Disciplines include nursing, medicine, PT, OT, respiratory therapy, psychology and social services
other considerations: Educating healthcare personnel about ICU delirium may be required(25)  –Researchers at Johns Hopkins Hospital in the United States found knowledge gaps in pediatric nurses about ICU delirium in the pediatric population. For example, 11% (12/105) incorrectly identified the Glasgow Coma Score as the appropriate screening tool, whereas the pCAM-ICU  is the correct test -The authors also found that 38% (40/105) thought that benzodiazepines were helpful in the treatment of ICU delirium
treatment summary: Evidence-based  guidelines are lacking on rehabilitation specifically for ICU delirium.Early mobilization appears effective for mechanically ventilated and criticallyill patients with delirium –Authors of an RCT in the United States found that early PT and OT mobilization in mechanicallyventilated, criticallyill patients decreased duration of delirium, increased ventilator-free  days, and increased the percentage of patients discharged with independent functional status. The ACCCM guidelines for PAD4are strongly based on results of this study(#) -Patients (n = 144) at two university hospitals were randomly assigned to either intervention group (early exercise and mobilizationduring periods of daily interruption of sedation) or a control group (daily interruption of sedation with therapy as ordered by primary care physician – normally after 2 weeks of mechanical ventilation) -To be included in study, patients had to be at least 18 years of age, on mechanical ventilation for 72 hours, expected to be on mechanical ventilation for at least 24 hours more, and to meet criteria for baseline independent functional independence -Independent functional independence was ability to perform 6 ADLs (bathing, dressing, eating, grooming, transferring bed to chair, and using toilet) and walking independently -Treatment sessions consisted of -Passive ROM of all limbs for unresponsive patients -Sedation interrupted and, once patient interaction was achieved, active-assisted  ROM and active ROM were initiated in supine position -Assuming tolerance of above, bed mobility activities were added, including transferring to upright sitting -ADLs were added, then transfer training and, finally, pre-gait  exercises and walking -Progression of activities was dependent on patient tolerance and stability -59% of patients in the invention group and 35% of patients in the control group returned to independent functional status. Average duration of delirium was 2 days for intervention group and 4 days for control group.Intervention group had 2 to 4 more days off mechanical ventilation than the control group -43% of patients in intervention group and 24% of patients in control group returned home -One adverse event (O2 desat < 80%) occurred in 498 therapy sessions and 19 sessions were discontinued, mostly for patient-ventilator  asynchrony –Authors of a systematic review with meta-analysis  found that nonpharmacological interventions that included exercise, patient education, and family participation were effective in reducing the occurrence and duration of ICU delirium(16) –In contrast, Authors of a 2015 systematic review and meta-analysis  found that early rehabilitation in the ICU was not associated with improvements in functional status, muscle strength, quality of life, or healthcare utilization outcomes. However, walking ability improved and the risk of ICU-acquired  weakness was reduced compared to usual care(17) -The authors acknowledged that their results differed from previous reviews and attributed differences to their inclusion of mobilization in usual care -Usual care was defined as encompassing passive ROM, position change every 2 hours while the patient was unconscious and once he or she regained consciousness, increasing the level of activity (first in an active-assisted  way with exercise in bed, progressing to sitting on the edge of bed, then transition from sitting to standing to finally reach ambulation [assisted or independent]) -In order to be considered rehabilitation, the intervention needed to include more components than usual care, be performed at a higher dose (intensity, volume, or frequency), or started at an earlier point than usual care –Authors of an RCT (N = 308 patients  who had received at least 48 hours of invasive or non-invasive  ventilation in the ICU) in the United Kingdom. The intervention group (n = 150) received a median of 161 min of physical rehabilitation while in ICU compared with 86 min in the control group (n = 158)(22) -The primary outcome was the Physical Component Summary (PCS) measure of SF-36  at 6 months. -Only 62 participants in the intervention group and 54 participants in the control group contributed primary outcome data -There was no difference in PCS between groups at 6 months: 37 in the intervention group and 37 in the control group –Authors of a systematic review with meta-analysis  found that early mobilization and rehabilitation of patients in the ICU was associated with a low safety event rate(29)  –Authors of a pilot trial (n = 87 medical and surgical ICU patients with respiratory failure)in the United States found that early rehabilitationin the ICU can be extended beyond PT and OT to include cognitive therapy(18)

An ICU in Canada reported the following early outcomes after joining the Canadian ICU Collaborative on Delirium:(19) –90% compliance with delirium screening –A 35% delirium incidence –A 50% increase in daily mobilizations –The elimination of almost all use of narcotic/benzodiazepine infusions –A decrease in restraint use to less than 15%

Authors of an online survey of 360 ICU healthcareprofessionals (nurses, physicians, and delirium consultants) from six ICUs in the Netherlands found that among the most important barriers to implementation of a guideline for treating ICU delirium were belief that delirium is not preventable, low satisfaction with physician-described  delirium management, poor collaboration between nurses and physicians, and the perception that a delirium guideline would be cumbersome or inconvenient in daily practice(20)

Authors of a 2017 systematic review with meta-analysis  (n = 7,546 patients in ICUs) found that 583 potential safety events (e.g., falls, removal of endotracheal tubes, removal or dysfunction of intravascular catheters, removal of other catheters/ tubes, cardiac arrest, hemodynamic changes, desaturation) occurred in 22,351 mobilization/rehabilitation sessions, a safety event rate of 2.6 per 100 sessions. Early mobilization and rehabilitation of patients in the ICU was associated with a low safety event rate(29) . maintenance or prevention: Patients should be assessed for change in delirium symptoms before and after daily sedative interruption(2,15)
Authors of a survey of nursing and medical staff in three district ICUs in the United Kingdomfound that ICU delirium is under recognized and screened for(3)

Authors of a 2015 systematic review of nonpharmacological interventions to prevent delirium found that evidence is lacking as to what nonpharmacological interventions should be used.However, they stated that a strong body of evidence does support the inclusion of patient education, reorientation of the patient with cognitive stimulation, and early mobilization(21)
Family and caregivers should receive education about ICU delirium and be involved in the patient’s ICU stay, as they will often detect changes in the patient’s status(26)

An RCT investigating standard vs. intensive physical rehabilitation in critical care is underway in the United Kingdom(22) 308 adult patients who have received more than 48 hours of noninvasive or invasive ventilation are enrolled Primary outcomes will be physical health at 6 months, measured by SF-36  Physical Component Summary. Secondary outcomes are assessment of mental health, ADLs, and delirium and ventilator-free  days, as well as a health economic analysis
